document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the Palearctic species of Macroglenes Westwood (Hymenoptera: Pteromalidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the Palearctic species of Macroglenes Westwood (Hymenoptera: Pteromalidae)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Corynocere deplana Nees, 1834 : 123
. Synonymy by
Graham, 1969
: 348
.
Pirene deplana
; Dalla
Tore, 1898
: 215
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. Body black, without metallic reflections; clypeal margin not incised (cf. Figs 1–2 ); funicle with all segments anelliform, without sensilla (Fig. 8 ); mesosoma flattened (Fig. 11 ); pecten on 1 / 2 – 2 / 3 length of hind tibia (cf. Fig. 14 ); forewing with mostly indistinct bare area between R and apical margin, basal cell with few hairs near basal vein; ovipositor sheaths slightly more than half length of hind tibia, hypopygium not reaching tip of gaster (Fig. 18 ). Male with eyes normal and scape inflated (cf. Fig. 7 ); mesosoma slightly more arched.

Variation. In some males and females F
5 may
be slightly but distinctly larger than F 4 , in some (rare) cases even having one sensillum; when males are involved it is thus sometimes rather difficult to decide if the specimen belongs to
M . varicornis
or
M . chalybeus
.

Comments. Easily distinguishable from other species in having all funicular segments anelliform, without sensilla (except rarely F 5 ) and entire clypeal margin. It seems to be one of the most common species in Europe.

Hosts. Known as a parasitoid of
Contarinia tritici
(various authors cited by
Noyes 2003
). Several specimens have been collected in alfalfa fields.
